required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Correlation Between Early Induction of Labor and Cesarean Delivery in Low-risk Nulliparous Women
clinical_study.official_title: Correlation Between Early Induction of Labor and Cesarean Delivery in Low-risk Nulliparous Women

brief_summary.textblock: To elucidate whether induction of labor in primiparas with low-risk pregnancies at 38 + 0 to 40 + 6 gestational weeks will increase the cesarean rate, compared with those receiving labor induction at more than 41+0 gestational weeks.

detailed_description.textblock: Medical records of all consecutive primiparas with low-risk pregnancy from January 1, 2014 to August 31, 2019 were reviewed to explore the correlation between early induction of labor and caesarean birth after 38 + 0 weeks. The hypothesis of the study is that induction of labor in primiparas with low-risk pregnancies at 38 + 0 to 40 + 6 gestational weeks will increase the cesarean rate, compared with those receiving labor induction at more than 41+0 gestational weeks.

intervention.description: Labor induction with oxytocin or prostagladin

study_pop.textblock: Medical records of all consecutive primiparas with low-risk pregnancy from January 1, 2014 to August 31, 2019

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- After 38 + 0 weeks of gestation
- low-risk pregnant primiparas
- singleton
- nulliparous
- > 20 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Premature rupture of membranes

facility.name: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Far-Eastern Memorial Hospital

responsible_party.investigator_title: Chief of Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology
